Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 19: Renunciation
Encompassing all the directions of space with the eye of the great elephant, the Bodhisattva declared:
Manual - English: The horse, Kaṇṭhaka, is decorated with jewels. Chandaka returns to the palace.  The horse is also known as “Faithful horse” (dad pa gser ldan), hence a trumpeter should be accompanied. This has no truthful basis, but is simply a rumor. Since the Indian drawing is authentic, it should be kept that way. A hunter offers a robe to the Buddha who then goes to shave his hair himself in front of a stupa. Gods collects hair. All three scenes above are the same as in the mainstream (p.17). There are sages in a forest with trees of golden leaves. The sages are upset when the forest turns into the “grove of noble trees” (shing 'phags pa'i tshal). The Buddha joins them in the forest.

Sun of Faith - English: So long as I will not have discovered the Supreme Path taught by all the buddhas,
I will not return to the city of Kapilavastu!
After covering twelve leagues, he dismounted.
Plucking off all his ornaments, he turned towards Chandaka:
"Take these jewels as well as the horse and go back to Kapilavastu."
His face wet with tears, Chandaka pleaded:
In this jungle full of tigers and lions, with trails of animal tracks everywhere,
How will you manage to survive, Lord, without the help of a single attendant?
The Bodhisattva retorted:Men are alone [=helpless] at their birth / And when they die, they die alone.
In the face of suffering, are they not alone? In the wheel of our lives, there are no friends.
A long argument ensued
Scene working notes: Taranatha's text elides this section of the argument from the Vinayavastu

Sun of Faith - English: Then the Bodhisattva caught up his sword, of which the blade was as fine as a blue lotus petal, and hacking off his long hair, flung the strands up into the sky.
Indra picked them up in the realm of the gods where he established a ritual to commemorate that sacred moment,
and had a stupa constructed.
Kanthaka, the best of horses, tenderly licked the Bodhisattva's feet.
“When I will have attained enlightenment,” Siddhartha promised as he patted its forehead, “I will keep in mind what you have done for me.”
To Chandaka he simply remarked: “Take Kanthaka back to the palace.”
Pulling the stallion by the reins, with a lump in his throat and eyes swimming, Chandaka went on his way. Every three paces, both horse and man would turn to have a last look at the Bodhisattva.
It took them seven days to reach the gates of Kapilavastu.
“I will never be able to enter the city with Kanthaka,” Chandaka moaned, “the crowd's sorrow will kill me.”
He stopped in one of the pleasure gardens then sent the steed alone towards the city gates.
Kanthaka whinnied and the people ran out of their houses.
Seeing the stallion with head low and the saddle empty of his beloved rider, the people hung at his neck sobbing and weeping.
His heart suffocating with all that grief, Kanthaka breathed his last and expired.
He was reborn in a family which diligently practised the six brahmanic virtues.
Meanwhile, in the forest, Indra took on the guise of an old hunter.
Wrapped in an orangeish fabric that a Pratyekabuddha [a Lone Realizer] of old had bequeathed to a forest sprite, he stationed himself by the wayside, bow and arrow in hand.

The Bodhisattva, who felt that his gorgeous diamond-worked robes were not suited to a life of renunciation,  felt that that saffron-colored jute cloth would be ideal for him. He offered to swap clothes with the hunter.

Bowing deeply at his feet, Indra offered his orangeish wrap to the Bodhisattva and took the latter's magnificent Benarsi silk garments, which he took away to the world of the Thirty-Three and made into an object of worship.
“If this wrap is not my size, may it become so,” the Bodhisattva made this wish and the saffron colored piece of cloth draped itself upon his body perfectly.
Thus attired in a renunciate's clothes the Bodhisattva came to the hermitage of the sage Bhagamva (Ngan spong gi bu).

Since the past twelve years palms and other fruit trees hung with leaves, flowers and fruits of solid gold had sprouted up of themselves. But that morning, the flowers and fruits looked like ordinary flowers and fruits.
Finding the sages plunged in deep thought, the Bodhisattva asked:“What makes you look so puzzled?”
“These trees of gold that are no longer so.”
“Earlier today,” explained the Bodhisattva, “the one whose power turned the hermitage trees to gold decided to spend the rest of his life as a religious mendicant.
Since he is no longer attracted by material objects, the plants look like normal plants. If he hadn't chosen to follow such a path, this forest would have become a pleasure garden.”

The sages stared hard at the Bodhisattva. They interrogated him for a long while, sensing somehow that the person standing before them was the very he whose power had caused the miracle. Siddhartha confirmed their feeling.
The ascetics then invited the Bodhisattva to sit upon a throne and placed at his feet, a basket wreathed with flowers and filled with fruit.
